Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN Collaborative Research: North American Lichens and Bryophytes: Sensitive Indicators of Environmental Quality and Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lichens and bryophytes share biological traits that make them some of the most sensitive indicators of environmental change. The goal of this project is to provide high quality data to address how species distributions change as a result of major environmental events across time and space. Specifically, this project will digitize the label information (the what, when, where and by whom collected) and images for approximately 2.3 million biological specimens curated in North American lichen and bryophyte herbaria. These collections represent well over 90% of all specimens collected in Canada, the United States and Mexico and held by over 60 US non-governmental institutions. New, on-line digitization techniques will be made publically available at at http://symbiota.org/nalichens/ and http://symbiota.org/bryophytes/, and will allow interested members of the public to be involved and learn about biodiversity alongside the professionals.

Availability of nearly the entire North American bryophyte and lichen collections on-line will greatly accelerate knowledge and evaluation of the biodiversity of these organisms by fostering collaborations between professionals and the general public. Additionally, models developed from these digitized data will aid future mapping projections of large scale species distributions and identification of biodiversity hotspots as prime candidates for protection. These endeavors will help to elucidate regions where changes are imminent and likely to have substantial impact, as well as to facilitate proactive initiatives to alleviate such changes. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological collections of museums and academic institutions document existing and extinct life forms as components of our planet’s present and past ecosystems and their changes over time. As such, biological collections are uniquely poised to inform the stewardship of life on Earth. Lichens and bryophytes share biological traits that make them some of the most sensitive indicators of environmental change. It is therefore important to have as many collections as possible digitized, with the data widely available. This is the principal goal of the collaborative project, the North American Lichens and Bryophytes Thematic Collections Network, led by Drs Corinna Gries and Thomas Nash from the University of Wisconsin. The Field Museum is one of about 70 institutions in this network, in total generating digital labels and accompanying label data of some 2.5 million specimens held in collections within the US; the Field Museum itself has generated over 180,000 specimen records and over 210,000 digital label images towards this ongoing endeavor. The ultimate goal is to provide high quality data to address how species distributions change as a result of major environmental events across time and space. The lichen portion of the project can be accessed at http://lichenportal.org/portal; the bryophyte portion at http://bryophyteportal.org/portal.  The award for this project was made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and, besides the aforementioned portals, all data resulting from this award are also available through the iDigBio portal coordinating all TCN projects.

Availability of nearly the entire North American bryophyte and lichen collections on-line will greatly accelerate knowledge and evaluation of the biodiversity of these organisms by fostering collaborations between professionals and the general public. Ecological models developed from these digitized data will aid future mapping projections of species distributions and identification of biodiversity hotspots as prime candidates for protection. These endeavors will help to elucidate regions where changes are imminent and likely to have substantial impact, as well as to facilitate proactive initiatives to alleviate such changes.

The Field Museum contributed strongly to public outreach and educational programs. Over the course of the project over 2,000 individual interactions have occurred with teachers, members of the general public, including teens, kids and families, highlighting biological collections and the significance of digitization efforts. A critical value-added component is the strong outreach program in coordination with the Learning Center and local universities, including a center for engagement of underrepresented students in science. This includes an ongoing partnership with the Student Center for Science Engagement (SCSE) at Northeastern Illinois University (NEIU) which ensured the recruitment of diverse and well qualified candidates underrepresented in science. The project has provided the impetus for a long-term annual partnership where SCSE will recruit and fund interns to pursue collections-based research and curation on bryophytes.
